verses.verse: Joshua turned back at that time and took Hazor, and struck its king with the sword; for Hazor was formerly the head of all those kingdoms.
And they struck all the people who were in it with the edge of the sword, (Deut. 20:16) utterly destroying them. There was none left (Josh. 10:40) breathing. Then he burned Hazor with fire.

So all the cities of those kings, and all their kings, Joshua took and struck with the edge of the sword. He utterly destroyed them, (Num. 33:50-56; Deut. 7:2; 20:16) as Moses the servant of the LORD had commanded.
But as for the cities that stood on their mounds, Israel burned none of them, except Hazor only, which Joshua burned.

And all the (Deut. 20:14-18) spoil of these cities and the livestock, the children of Israel took as booty for themselves; but they struck every man with the edge of the sword until they had destroyed them, and they left none breathing.
(Ex. 34:10-17) As the LORD had commanded Moses his servant, so (Deut. 31:7, 8) Moses commanded Joshua, and (Josh. 1:7) so Joshua did. He left nothing undone of all that the LORD had commanded Moses.

(Summary of Joshua’s Conquests) Thus Joshua took all this land: (Josh. 12:8) the mountain country, all the South, (Josh. 10:40, 41) all the land of Goshen, the lowland, and the Jordan plain—the mountains of Israel and its lowlands,

(Josh. 12:7) from Mount Halak and the ascent to Seir, even as far as Baal Gad in the Valley of Lebanon below Mount Hermon. He captured (Deut. 7:24) all their kings, and struck them down and killed them.
Joshua made war a long time with all those kings.
There was not a city that made peace with the children of Israel, except (Josh. 9:3-7) the Hivites, the inhabitants of Gibeon. All the others they took in battle.

For (Deut. 2:30) it was of the LORD to harden their hearts, that they should come against Israel in battle, that He might utterly destroy them, and that they might receive no mercy, but that He might destroy them, (Deut. 20:16, 17) as the LORD had commanded Moses.

And at that time Joshua came and cut off (Num. 13:22, 33; Deut. 1:28; 9:2; Josh. 15:13, 14) the Anakim from the mountains: from Hebron, from Debir, from Anab, from all the mountains of Judah, and from all the mountains of Israel; Joshua utterly destroyed them with their cities.
None of the Anakim were left in the land of the children of Israel; they remained only (1 Sam. 17:4) in Gaza, in Gath, (Josh. 15:46; 1 Sam. 5:1; Is. 20:1) and in Ashdod.

So Joshua took the whole land, (Ex. 33:2; Num. 34:2-15) according to all that the LORD had said to Moses; and Joshua gave it as an inheritance to Israel (Num. 26:53; Josh. 14; 15) according to their divisions by their tribes. Then the land (Deut. 12:9, 10; 25:19; (Heb. 4:8)) rested from war.

(The Kings Conquered by Moses) These are the kings of the land whom the children of Israel defeated, and whose land they possessed on the other side of the Jordan toward the rising of the sun, (Num. 21:24) from the River Arnon (Deut. 3:8) to Mount Hermon, and all the eastern Jordan plain:

One king was (Num. 21:24; Deut. 2:24-27) Sihon king of the Amorites, who dwelt in Heshbon and ruled half of Gilead, from Aroer, which is on the bank of the River Arnon, from the middle of that river, even as far as the River Jabbok, which is the border of the Ammonites,

and (Deut. 3:17) the eastern Jordan plain from the Sea of Chinneroth as far as the Sea of the Arabah (the Salt Sea), (Josh. 13:20) the road to Beth Jeshimoth, and southward below (Deut. 3:17; 4:49) the slopes of Pisgah.
The other king was (Num. 21:33; Deut. 3:4, 10) Og king of Bashan and his territory, who was of (Deut. 3:11; Josh. 13:12) the remnant of the giants, (Deut. 1:4) who dwelt at Ashtaroth and at Edrei,

and reigned over (Deut. 3:8) Mount Hermon, (Deut. 3:10; Josh. 13:11; 1 Chr. 5:11) over Salcah, over all Bashan, (Deut. 3:14; 1 Sam. 27:8) as far as the border of the Geshurites and the Maachathites, and over half of Gilead to the border of Sihon king of Heshbon.

(Num. 21:24, 35) These Moses the servant of the LORD and the children of Israel had conquered; and (Num. 32:29-33; Deut. 3:12; Josh. 13:8) Moses the servant of the LORD had given it as a possession to the Reubenites, the Gadites, and half the tribe of Manasseh.

(The Kings Conquered by Joshua) And these are the kings of the country (Josh. 11:17) which Joshua and the children of Israel conquered on this side of the Jordan, on the west, from Baal Gad in the Valley of Lebanon as far as Mount Halak and the ascent to (Gen. 14:6; 32:3; Deut. 2:1, 4) Seir, which Joshua (Josh. 11:23) gave to the tribes of Israel as a possession according to their divisions,

(Josh. 10:40; 11:16) in the mountain country, in the lowlands, in the Jordan plain, in the slopes, in the wilderness, and in the South— (Ex. 3:8; 23:23; Josh. 9:1) the Hittites, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites:
(Josh. 6:2) the king of Jericho, one; (Josh. 8:29) the king of Ai, which is beside Bethel, one;
(Josh. 10:23) the king of Jerusalem, one; the king of Hebron, one;
